fields.prompt: The author criticizes the “the historical annalist” (first sentence) for

fields.prompt: As it is used in the first sentence of the last paragraph, the word “for” most nearly means
explanations: You may have thought by “paid more attention” that the author means humanists have failed to direct their attention toward practical inventions. However, the context of the sentence supports a different meaning.

You may have reasoned that humanists should have regarded “practical inventive genius” more favorably in their interpretation of history. However, the author notes that this disregard does not diminish the fact that these innovations occurred.

You may have thought that humanists would have replaced their misconceptions with the reality of technological developments if they had paid more attention. However, the author notes these innovations continued to function despite the views of humanists.
You may have focused on the fact that technological developments continued “although” they were disregarded by humanists. However, this is not what “for” indicates in the sentence.

The author states that humanists would have changed their views of the “dark ages” if they had “paid more attention” to “the practical inventive genius” that was alive and well even though the Roman Empire had fallen.

fields.prompt: The passage suggests that the humanists viewed “medieval society” (last sentence) with
explanations: In the last sentence the author concludes that humanists had conceived “contempt” for medieval society by ignoring the value of the “practical inventive genius” of the people and labeling the entire era as a “dark ages.”

You may have thought that humanists revered a “high intellectual tradition” on which they based their judgments about medieval society. However, the author notes it is this reverence that caused humanists disregard the practical achievements of regular people.
You may have inferred that the conflicting ideas about medieval society show that humanists had mixed feelings. However, the context suggests they did not have any doubts about their beliefs.

You may have reasoned that humanists were curious and “peered backward” to investigate their history. However, the passage suggests that they had a lack of curiosity because they ignored the practical achievements of medieval society.

You may have thought that the unfavorable impression humanists had of medieval society as living in “dark ages” suggests that they felt dismay at the decline of the intellectual tradition. However, there is no evidence suggesting they were alarmed.

fields.prompt: Ava, Cara, Emma, Lily, and Mia are to be seated together in a row. If Emma and Lily must sit next to each other, how many different ways can the five girls be seated?
